title: Ticket #3516: ProcLog on MacOSX shows error on startup.
description:
BaTLab MacOSX machine exec-22 shows this error in the ProcLog upon startup: 
02/25/13 12:15:25 : ***********************************
02/25/13 12:15:25 : * condor_procd STARTING UP
02/25/13 12:15:25 : * PID = 21206
02/25/13 12:15:25 : * UID = 0
02/25/13 12:15:25 : * GID = 0
02/25/13 12:15:25 : ***********************************
02/25/13 12:15:25 : Procd has a watcher pid and will die if pid 21203 dies.
02/25/13 12:15:25 : taking a snapshot...
02/25/13 12:15:25 : ProcAPI: task_port_pid() on pid 0 failed with 5((os/kern) failure), Marking imgsize,
 rsssize, cpu/sys time as zero for the pid.
02/25/13 12:15:25 : method PID: found family 21203 for process 21203
02/25/13 12:15:25 : method PARENT: found family 21203 for process 21206
02/25/13 12:15:25 : method PARENT: found family 21203 for process 21206 (already determined)
remarks:
2013-Feb-25 14:08:58 by tannenba:
Key in the above to me is the "...on pid 0 failed..." part of the log. Of course getting info on pid 0 is going to fail, why is the procd trying to look at pid 0 in the first place?

2013-Mar-11 18:46:14 by tannenba:
Maybe related to #2537 ? If not perhaps #2537 should be resolved or abandoned?

2013-Apr-24 13:02:49 by zmiller:
here's a potentially illumniating comment from gquinn in 2007: 

        Depending upon how the user machine is configured, task_for_pid() could
        work or not work when a process is not running as root. As of macos
        10.4, the default is 0. However, since an admin may configure their
        machine to have a process utilize task_for_pid when it isn't running
        as root, we allow the admin to tell Condor about this.

        As for 09/05/2007 for macosx 10.3 & 10.4, these are the
        applicable values.

        Old policy is:
            - the caller is running as root (EUID 0)
            - if the caller is running as the
                same UID as the target (and the target's
                EUID matches its RUID, that is, it's not
                running a setuid binary)
        New policy is:
            - if the caller was running as root (EUID 0)
            - if the pid is that of the caller
            - if the caller is running as the same UID
                as the target and the target's EUID matches
                its RUID, that is, it's not a setuid binary
                AND the caller is in group "procmod" or
                "procview"

                The long term goal of having both "procmod"
                and "procview" is that task_for_pid would
                return a send right for the task control
                port only to those processes in "procmod";
                the callers in "procview" would only get a
                send right to a task inspection port.  This
                distinction is not currently implemented.

        To actually set the policy, do this:

        $ sudo sysctl -w kern.tfp.policy=1 #set old policy
        $ sudo sysctl -w kern.tfp.policy=2 #set new policy
        $ sudo sysctl -w kern.tfp.policy=0 #disable task_for_pid except for root

        Since I can't seem to find a man page for task_for_pid() *anywhere*,
        which is odd, I'm going to declare that if it comes back not a
        KERN_SUCCESS, then I don't have permission to see the pid. Sadly,
        I can't tell if a pid is not there, or I don't have a permission
        to see it using this method.

I'm just waiting for an account so I can inspect those settings and the procd logs.

2013-Apr-26 12:52:15 by zmiller:
the above is interesting but not the problem here. kern.tfp.policy is already set to "2" on the node i examined. so there must be some other reason we are getting "0" from task_for_pid. continuing to investigate.

2013-May-16 14:46:30 by jfrey:
Pid 0 is pseudo-process named "kernel_task" that represents the kernel. It doesn't show up in ps, but does show up in the Activity Monitor application. Since it's not a real process that can be manipulated, I propose we ignore it when building the full list of pids on the system.
check_ins:
2013-May-23 13:42   Check-in [35844]: Version history for pid 0 errors on mac. #3516 (By Jaime Frey )
2013-May-16 16:49   Check-in [35719]: Ignore pid 0 in procapi on macosx. #3516 The full list of pids returned by sysctl() on MacOSX include pid 0, which is not a real userland process. It's named kernel_task and represents the kernel. Calls like task_for_pid() fail on it, leading to worrying messages in the procd log. Ignore it in ProcAPI::buildPidList(). [...] (By Jaime Frey )
